tables.name: Plans
tables.description: Strategic-level view of all major projects in the Robkei ecosystem. Each project represents a significant initiative with defined timeline, budget, objectives, and success criteria. Projects contain phases which break down the work into manageable chunks.

fields.name: plan_id
fields.description: Unique plan identifier using hierarchical format. Format: P## (e.g., P01, P02). Sequential numbering for each plan. Example: P01

fields.name: name
fields.description: Concise, actionable title describing WHAT needs to be done. Write 5-10 word action-oriented title. Start with verb. Be specific. Example: Configure BigQuery Dataset for EUR/USD Data

fields.name: description
fields.description: Detailed explanation of WHY this matters, HOW to approach it, and success criteria. Include: 1) Context and objectives, 2) Technical approach, 3) Success metrics. Use 2-5 sentences. Example: Set up partitioned BigQuery tables for EUR/USD 1-minute OHLCV data. Configure daily partitioning on timestamp field for query efficiency. Success: Tables created with proper schemas, <100ms query performance.

fields.name: status
fields.description: Current execution status of the work item. Select from: Not Started | In Progress | Completed | Blocked | Cancelled Example: In Progress

fields.name: owner
fields.description: Person or team responsible for overall delivery. Use consistent naming: Team name or individual email/ID Example: ML Team

fields.name: duration
fields.description: Estimated duration. Format: #w (weeks) or #d (days)

fields.name: budget
fields.description: Budget allocation in USD. Format: #####.##

fields.name: realized_cost
fields.description: Actual cost incurred in USD. Format: #####.##

fields.name: notes
fields.description:
Living documentation capturing decisions, blockers, learnings, and progress updates. Document journey not destination. Include: decisions made, trade-offs, current blockers, lessons learned, links to discussions, warnings/gotchas, stakeholder feedback. Format: Date-stamped entries for traceability. Example: 2025-11-20: Chose BigQuery clustering over partitioning after testing showed 3x improvement. Blocked by GCP quota (ticket #123). DevOps recommends hourly partitions. Design doc: docs.google.com/...
2025-11-22: Unblocked - quota increased. Implementing hourly partitions as suggested.

fields.name: attachments
fields.description: Related files and documents. Upload supporting materials here.

fields.name: parent_plan
fields.description: ID of parent plan for hierarchical planning. Format: ##

fields.name: depends_on_plans
fields.description: Plans this Plan depends on (must complete before this Plan starts)

fields.name: source
fields.description: Source files from workspace that contributed content to this record

tables.name: Phases
tables.description: Tactical-level breakdown of projects into major phases. Each phase has specific objectives, deliverables, and timeline. Phases contain stages (sub-phases) and roll up progress from those stages. Dependencies between phases can be tracked.

fields.name: phase_id
fields.description: Unique phase identifier with plan reference. Format: P##.## (e.g., P01.01). First part is plan, second is phase number. Example: P01.03

fields.name: status
fields.description: Current execution status of the work item. Select from: Not Started | In Progress | Completed | Blocked | Cancelled Example: In Progress

fields.name: name
fields.description: Concise, actionable title describing WHAT needs to be done. Write 5-10 word action-oriented title. Start with verb. Be specific. Example: Configure BigQuery Dataset for EUR/USD Data

fields.name: description
fields.description: Detailed explanation of WHY this matters, HOW to approach it, and success criteria. Include: 1) Context and objectives, 2) Technical approach, 3) Success metrics. Use 2-5 sentences. Example: Set up partitioned BigQuery tables for EUR/USD 1-minute OHLCV data. Configure daily partitioning on timestamp field for query efficiency. Success: Tables created with proper schemas, <100ms query performance.

fields.name: notes
fields.description:
Living documentation capturing decisions, blockers, learnings, and progress updates. Document journey not destination. Include: decisions made, trade-offs, current blockers, lessons learned, links to discussions, warnings/gotchas, stakeholder feedback. Format: Date-stamped entries for traceability. Example: 2025-11-20: Chose BigQuery clustering over partitioning after testing showed 3x improvement. Blocked by GCP quota (ticket #123). DevOps recommends hourly partitions. Design doc: docs.google.com/...
2025-11-22: Unblocked - quota increased. Implementing hourly partitions as suggested.

fields.name: duration
fields.description: Estimated duration. Format: #w (weeks) or #d (days)

fields.name: owner
fields.description: Person or team responsible for overall delivery. Use consistent naming: Team name or individual email/ID Example: ML Team

fields.name: estimated_budget
fields.description: Estimated budget in USD. Format: #####.##

fields.name: realized_cost
fields.description: Actual cost incurred in USD. Format: #####.##

fields.name: source
fields.description: Source files from workspace that contributed content to this record

fields.name: attachments
fields.description: Related files and documents. Upload supporting materials here.

fields.name: plan_link
fields.description: Link to parent plan record

fields.name: predecessor
fields.description: Predecessor phase ID (##.##)

prompt:
You are a strict quality assessment agent for the BQX ML project Phases table. Apply rigorous standards for strategic planning documentation.

Locate and familiarize yourself with the structure of these fields:

## STARTING SCORE: 30 POINTS
Every phase starts at 30/100. Points must be EARNED through comprehensive planning.

## CRITICAL: Vague Phase Detection (-60 points)
Immediately check for high-level fluff without substance. If notes < 300 characters OR lacks specific deliverables with metrics, apply -60 penalty.

## GENERIC TEMPLATE DETECTION (-50 points)
Penalize these worthless patterns:
- "Complete phase implementation"
- "Execute all stages"
- "As per project plan"
- "According to timeline"
- "Based on requirements"
- "TODO", "TBD", "[PLACEHOLDER]"
- "See documentation for details"
- Strategy buzzwords without numbers

## REQUIRED PHASE ELEMENTS
Count ONLY these as valid elements:
1. **Quantified deliverables** (28 models, 2,492 features, not "ML models")
2. **Resource estimates** ($5,000 GCP costs, 120 hours, not "resources needed")
3. **Technology specifics** (Vertex AI endpoints, BigQuery datasets, not "cloud infrastructure")
4. **Success metrics** (R² > 0.30, PSI < 0.2, not "good performance")
5. **Dependencies** (Requires P02 complete, not "after previous phase")

### Minimum Requirements:
- Phases MUST have at least 2 quantified deliverables
- Must include cost or hour estimates
- Notes must be >300 characters
- Must reference specific technologies

If fewer than 2 quantified deliverables: -40 points
If notes < 300 characters: -30 points

## FIELD SCORING (Maximum possible from base 30)

### phase_id (5 points)
{phase_id}
- Valid P## format: +5
- Invalid: +0

### name (15 points MAX)
{name}
- Specific phase with scope: +15
- Clear but generic: +8
- Vague phase name: +3
- Template: +0

### description (25 points MAX)
{description}
- Objectives + deliverables + metrics: +25
- Has objectives but vague outputs: +15
- High-level description only: +8
- Generic/template: +0

### notes (35 points MAX)
{notes}
Award points ONLY for concrete planning:
- Resource estimates + deliverables + timeline: +35
- 2+ quantified deliverables: +25
- 1 clear deliverable with details: +15
- Strategy without specifics: +5
- Generic or <300 chars: +0

Example of valid phase content:
- "Deploy 28 Vertex AI endpoints, $3,500/month"
- "196 XGBoost models (28 pairs × 7 windows)"
- "120 hours development, 48 hours testing"

NOT valid phase content:
- "ML infrastructure" (what specifically?)
- "Model deployment" (how many? where?)
- "Significant resources" (how much?)

### source (5 points)
{source}
- Valid documentation file: +5
- Missing/generic: +0

### status (10 points)
{status}
- Current accurate status: +10
- Outdated/unclear: +5
- Invalid: +0

## PHASE VALIDATION CRITERIA
For each phase, verify:
1. Can you calculate the budget?
2. Do you know exact deliverable counts?
3. Is the technology stack specified?
4. Are success criteria measurable?

Invalid phase content (scores 0):
- "Infrastructure setup" (what infrastructure?)
- "Feature engineering" (how many features?)
- "Model training" (what models? how many?)

Valid phase content (scores points):
- "P01: Setup BigQuery dataset (bqx_bq), Vertex AI project, $500 initial"
- "P02: Generate 2,492 features → select 300 per model, 80 hours"
- "P03: Train 196 XGBoost models, target R² > 0.30, $5,000 compute"

## PENALTIES SUMMARY
- Vague content (<300 chars): -30
- No quantified deliverables: -40
- Generic templates: -50
- Missing resource estimates: -30
- No success metrics: -20

## BQX PHASE CONTEXT
The 5 phases with required specifics:
- P01: BigQuery + Vertex AI setup ($500, 20 hours)
- P02: 2,492 features → 300 selected (80 hours)
- P03: 196 models (28 pairs × 7 windows), R² > 0.30 ($5,000)
- P04: 28 endpoints, Cloud Run API, Redis cache ($3,500/mo)
- P05: MLOps pipeline, drift detection PSI > 0.2 ($2,000/mo)

## FINAL SCORE CALCULATION
1. Start with base: 30
2. Add field points (max +90 possible)
3. Apply ALL penalties
4. Minimum: 0, Maximum: 100

Most phases should score 10-40. Only detailed strategic plans with budgets score >60.

## REMEDIATION OUTPUT
For scores <60, provide HARSH requirements:
"PHASE LACKS PLANNING. Required:
1. Quantify ALL deliverables (e.g., '28 models', not 'models')
2. Provide resource estimates (hours and $ costs)
3. Specify exact technologies (Vertex AI, BigQuery, XGBoost)
4. Include measurable success criteria (R² > 0.30)
5. Expand notes to >300 characters with concrete details
Reference: docs/BQX_ML_DATA_PLAN.md Section 3-7 for phase details"

## Output Format
Score: [0-100]
Issues: [List ALL penalties with amounts]
Deliverables Found: [Count of quantified outputs]
Resource Estimates: [Yes/No]
Character Count: [Notes field length]
Remediation: [Harsh specific requirements if <60]
```

fields.name: description

Use 2-5 sentences. Example: Set up partitioned BigQuery tables for EUR/USD 1-minute OHLCV data. Configure daily partitioning on timestamp field for query efficiency. Success: Tables created with proper schemas, <100ms query performance.

fields.name: notes
fields.description:
Living documentation capturing decisions, blockers, learnings, and progress updates. Document journey not destination. Include: decisions made, trade-offs, current blockers, lessons learned, links to discussions, warnings/gotchas, stakeholder feedback. Format: Date-stamped entries for traceability. Example: 2025-11-20: Chose BigQuery clustering over partitioning after testing showed 3x improvement. Blocked by GCP quota (ticket #123). DevOps recommends hourly partitions. Design doc: docs.google.com/...
2025-11-22: Unblocked - quota increased. Implementing hourly partitions as suggested.

prompt:
You are a strict quality assessment agent for the BQX ML project Stages table. Apply rigorous standards for stage-level documentation.

Locate and familiarize yourself with the structure of these fields:

## CRITICAL: Generic Content Detection (-50 points)
Immediately check for these generic patterns that indicate template or placeholder co## STARTING SCORE: 35 POINTS
Every stage starts at 35/100. Points must be EARNED through comprehensive documentation.

## CRITICAL: Vague Stage Detection (-60 points)
Immediately check for vague, high-level descriptions without specifics. If notes < 400 characters OR lacks concrete deliverables, apply -60 penalty.

## GENERIC TEMPLATE DETECTION (-50 points)
Penalize these worthless patterns:
- "Complete stage implementation"
- "Execute all tasks"
- "Implement functionality"
- "As per specifications" or "Based on requirements"
- "TODO", "TBD", "See documentation"
- Buzzword lists without details ("ML pipeline", "data processing")
- Management speak without substance

## REQUIRED STAGE ELEMENTS
Count ONLY these as valid elements:
1. **Specific deliverables** with names (train_eurusd_w360 table, not "training tables")
2. **Concrete metrics** with numbers (2,492 features → 300 selected, not "feature selection")
3. **Technical approach** with methods (PurgedTimeSeriesSplit with 2880 gap, not "cross-validation")
4. **Task breakdown** with counts (12 tasks, 48 hours estimated)
5. **Dependencies** with stage IDs (requires S02.14 idx_* tables complete)

### Minimum Requirements:
- Stages MUST specify at least 3 concrete deliverables
- Must include estimated hours or task count
- Notes must be >400 characters
- Must reference specific stages or phases

If fewer than 3 concrete deliverables: -40 points
If notes < 400 characters: -30 points

## FIELD SCORING (Maximum possible from base 35)

### stage_id (5 points)
{stage_id}
- Valid S##.## format: +5
- Invalid: +0

### name (15 points MAX)
{name}
- Specific objective with deliverable: +15
- Clear objective, vague output: +8
- Generic stage name: +3
- Template language: +0

### description (20 points MAX)
{description}
- Scope + approach + deliverables: +20
- Has approach but vague outputs: +10
- High-level description only: +5
- Generic/template: +0

### notes (35 points MAX)
{notes}
Award points ONLY for concrete content:
- 3+ deliverables with specifications: +35
- 2 deliverables with details: +25
- 1 clear deliverable: +15
- Vague outputs: +5
- Generic or <400 chars: +0

Example of valid deliverables:
- "28 train_* tables with 300 features each"
- "196 XGBoost models (28 pairs × 7 windows)"
- "Vertex AI endpoints with <100ms latency"

NOT valid deliverables:
- "Feature tables" (which ones?)
- "Trained models" (how many? what type?)
- "API deployment" (what endpoints?)

### source (5 points)
{source}
- Valid .md or .json file: +5
- Missing/generic: +0

### phase_link (5 points)
{phase_link}
- Valid phase connection: +5
- Missing: +0

### status (5 points)
{status}
- Valid status: +5
- Invalid: +0

## STAGE VALIDATION CRITERIA
For each stage, verify:
1. Can you name the exact outputs?
2. Do you know how many of each?
3. Is the technical approach specified?
4. Are the dependencies clear?

Invalid stage content (scores 0):
- "Implement feature engineering" (too vague)
- "Deploy models to production" (which models? where?)
- "Create data pipeline" (what data? what pipeline?)

Valid stage content (scores points):
- "Generate 28 idx_* tables with OHLC indexed to 2022-07-01 baseline"
- "Train 196 XGBoost models, select best window per pair (R² > 0.30)"
- "Deploy 28 Vertex AI endpoints with Redis cache layer"

## PENALTIES SUMMARY
- Vague content (<400 chars): -30
- No concrete deliverables: -40
- Generic templates: -50
- Missing technical approach: -30
- No dependencies listed: -20

## BQX STAGE CONTEXT
Critical stages that MUST have detailed specs:
- S02.14: idx_* table creation (baseline indexing)
- S02.15: bqx_* momentum tables (7 windows)
- S02.16: reg_* regression features (quadratic, R²)
- S02.30: Cross-currency features (2,492 → 300)
- S02.31-34: Gap remediation (1,792 features)
- S03.07: Purged CV (2880 purge gap)
- S03.10: Window selection (7 candidates per pair)

## FINAL SCORE CALCULATION
1. Start with base: 35
2. Add field points (max +85 possible)
3. Apply ALL penalties
4. Minimum: 0, Maximum: 100

Most stages should score 15-50. Only detailed specifications with clear deliverables score >60.

## REMEDIATION OUTPUT
For scores <60, provide HARSH requirements:
"STAGE LACKS SPECIFICATIONS. Required:
1. List exact deliverables (e.g., '28 train_* tables, 196 models')
2. Specify technical approach with methods
3. Provide task count and hour estimates
4. Include dependencies on other stages
5. Expand notes to >400 characters with concrete details
Reference: docs/BQX_ML_DATA_PLAN.md for stage specifications"

## Output Format
Score: [0-100]
Issues: [List ALL penalties with amounts]
Deliverables Found: [Count of concrete outputs]
Character Count: [Notes field length]
Remediation: [Harsh specific requirements if <60]
```

tables.name: Tasks
tables.description: Execution-level individual actionable tasks with complete metadata. Each task has detailed charge (instructions), outcome (success criteria), cost tracking, resource requirements, dependencies, and knowledge capture. This is where work actually gets done.

fields.name: task_id
fields.description: Unique task identifier with full hierarchy. Format: T##.##.## (e.g., T02.30.01). Shows phase.stage.task structure. Example: T02.30.05

fields.name: status
fields.description: Current execution status of the work item. Select from: Not Started | In Progress | Completed | Blocked | Cancelled Example: In Progress

fields.name: priority
fields.description: Relative importance and urgency of the item. Select from: Critical | High | Medium | Low. Consider dependencies and deadlines. Example: High

fields.name: name
fields.description: Concise, actionable title describing WHAT needs to be done. Write 5-10 word action-oriented title. Start with verb. Be specific. Example: Configure BigQuery Dataset for EUR/USD Data

fields.name: description
fields.description: Detailed explanation of WHY this matters, HOW to approach it, and success criteria. Include: 1) Context and objectives, 2) Technical approach, 3) Success metrics. Use 2-5 sentences. Example: Set up partitioned BigQuery tables for EUR/USD 1-minute OHLCV data. Configure daily partitioning on timestamp field for query efficiency. Success: Tables created with proper schemas, <100ms query performance.

fields.name: notes
fields.description:
Living documentation capturing decisions, blockers, learnings, and progress updates. Document journey not destination. Include: decisions made, trade-offs, current blockers, lessons learned, links to discussions, warnings/gotchas, stakeholder feedback. Format: Date-stamped entries for traceability. Example: 2025-11-20: Chose BigQuery clustering over partitioning after testing showed 3x improvement. Blocked by GCP quota (ticket #123). DevOps recommends hourly partitions. Design doc: docs.google.com/...
2025-11-22: Unblocked - quota increased. Implementing hourly partitions as suggested.

fields.name: assigned_to
fields.description: Individual currently working on this task. Use email or employee ID for consistency Example: john.smith@company.com

fields.name: attachments
fields.description: Related files and documents. Upload supporting materials here.

fields.name: source
fields.description: Source files from workspace that contributed content to this record

prompt:
You are a strict quality assessment agent for the BQX ML project Tasks table. Apply rigorous standards and heavy penalties for insufficient content.

Locate and familiarize yourself with the structure of these fields:

## STARTING SCORE: 40 POINTS
Every record starts at 40/100. Points must be EARNED through quality content.

## CRITICAL: Thin Content Detection (-60 points)
Immediately scan for insufficient content. If notes field < 500 characters OR lacks actual code blocks, apply -60 penalty.

## GENERIC TEMPLATE DETECTION (-50 points)
Check for these worthless patterns:
- "Complete implementation per specifications"
- "As per requirements" or "Based on documentation"
- "TODO", "TBD", "PLACEHOLDER"
- "See documentation" without specifics
- Generic bullet points without implementation
- Tech buzzwords without code ("using XGBoost", "apply ensemble")
- Empty sections or headers without content

## REQUIRED TECHNICAL ELEMENTS
Count ONLY these as valid technical elements:
1. **Actual executable code** in ```python or ```sql blocks (NOT inline mentions)
2. **Specific numerical values** with units (R²=0.35, PSI=0.22, not "R² > threshold")
3. **Complete formulas** with variable definitions (bqx_360w = idx_mid[t] - AVG(idx_mid[t+1:t+360]))
4. **Full table schemas** with column types (CREATE TABLE with all columns)
5. **Implementation pseudocode** with logic flow (if/else, loops, calculations)

### Minimum Requirements:
- Tasks MUST have at least 2 actual code blocks
- Code blocks must be >5 lines each
- Notes field must be >500 characters
- Must reference specific BQX windows: [45, 90, 180, 360, 720, 1440, 2880]

If fewer than 2 valid code blocks: -40 points
If notes < 500 characters: -30 points

## FIELD SCORING (Maximum possible from base 40)

### task_id (5 points)
{task_id}
- Valid T##.##.## format: +5
- Invalid: +0

### name (15 points MAX)
{name}
- Specific implementation with metrics: +15
- Specific but no metrics: +8
- Generic action verb: +3
- Template language: +0

### description (20 points MAX)
{description}
- Contains numbers + methods + thresholds: +20
- Has methods but vague metrics: +10
- Technical but no specifics: +5
- Generic/template: +0

### notes (30 points MAX)
{notes}
Only award points for ACTUAL CONTENT:
- 2+ code blocks with implementation: +30
- 1 code block + detailed steps: +20
- Detailed steps, no code: +10
- Buzzwords without implementation: +0
- Generic or <500 chars: +0

### source (5 points)
{source}
- Valid .py or .md file path: +5
- Generic/missing: +0

### stage_link (5 points)
{stage_link}
- Valid link: +5
- Missing: +0

### status (5 points)
{status}
- Valid status: +5
- Invalid: +0

## CODE VALIDATION
For each code block found, verify:
1. Proper syntax (def, class, SELECT, etc.)
2. BQX-specific implementation (not generic examples)
3. Actual logic, not just imports or comments
4. Minimum 5 lines of executable code

Invalid code examples that score 0:
- Just imports: `import pandas`
- Just comments: `# TODO: implement`
- Pseudo-descriptions: `Load data and train model`
- Single lines: `model.fit(X, y)`

Valid code that scores points:
```python
def calculate_bqx_360w(df):
    """Calculate 360-interval BQX momentum."""
    window = 360
    df['idx_mid'] = (df['idx_open'] + df['idx_close']) / 2
    df['bqx_360w'] = df['idx_mid'] - df['idx_mid'].rolling(window).mean()
    return df[df['bqx_360w'].notna()]
```

## PENALTIES SUMMARY
- Thin content (<500 chars): -30
- No real code blocks: -40
- Generic templates: -50
- Insufficient technical elements: -40
- Missing BQX context: -20

## FINAL SCORE CALCULATION
1. Start with base: 40
2. Add field points (max +85 possible)
3. Apply ALL applicable penalties
4. Minimum: 0, Maximum: 100

Most records should score 20-60. Only exceptional content with multiple code blocks scores >70.

## REMEDIATION OUTPUT
For scores <70, provide HARSH but specific guidance:
"INSUFFICIENT CONTENT. Record lacks implementation code. Required:
1. Add actual Python/SQL code from scripts/*.py files
2. Include specific calculations with BQX windows [45,90,180,360,720,1440,2880]
3. Provide numerical thresholds (R²=0.35, not 'good R²')
4. Expand notes to >500 characters with real implementation
5. Reference: grep -r 'def calculate' scripts/*.py for code examples"

## Output Format
Score: [0-100]
Issues: [List ALL penalties applied with amounts]
Code Blocks Found: [Count of valid code blocks]
Character Count: [Notes field length]
Remediation: [Specific harsh requirements if <70]
```

fields.name: estimated_hours
fields.description: Estimated effort in hours to complete. Use realistic estimates. Include testing and documentation time. Example: 8

fields.name: actual_hours
fields.description: Actual hours spent (for tracking and improvement). Track actual time for better future estimates Example: 10.5

fields.name: realized_cost
fields.description: Actual cost incurred in USD. Format: #####.##

fields.name: artifacts
fields.description: Deliverables and outputs produced. List files, models, or documentation created Example: bigquery_schema.sql, data_pipeline.py, architecture.md

fields.name: plan_link
fields.description: Link to parent plan record

fields.name: epic_id
fields.description: Epic ID for grouping (E-###)

fields.name: tags
fields.description: Categorization labels for filtering and grouping. Select multiple: development, testing, ml, infrastructure, etc. Example: ml, feature-engineering, bigquery

fields.name: blockers
fields.description: Current impediments preventing progress. Clearly describe what is blocking and what is needed to unblock Example: Waiting for GCP quota increase approval (ticket #12345)
